data.text:
The Messenger‚Ä¶

About the Book:

Meet Ed Kennedy ‚Äì cab driving prodigy, pathetic card player and useless at sex (self-proclaimed). He lives in a suburban shack, shares coffee with his dog, the Doorman, and he‚Äôs in nervous love with Audrey. His life is one of peaceful routine and incompetence ‚Äì until he inadvertently stops a bank robbery.

That‚Äôs when the first Ace turns up.

That‚Äôs when Ed becomes the messenger.

Chosen to care, he makes his way through town, helping and hurting (where necessary) until only one question remains. Who‚Äôs behind Ed‚Äôs mission?

Protect the diamonds, survive the clubs, dig deep through spades, feel the hearts‚Ä¶ The Messenger is a cryptic journey filled with laughter, fists and love.

My Thoughts:

There‚Äôs a story as to why I‚Äôve read The Messenger at this point in time, and it‚Äôs only partially to do with my book bingo category of ‚Äòread a book that is more than 10 years old‚Äô. Truth is, I had never read a Markus Zusak novel before now. I‚Äôll let that rest with you for a moment, I know, it‚Äôs almost un-Australian of me. Not even The Book Thief. Yep. That‚Äôs right. Even my daughter, who hardly ever reads, loves The Book Thief. It‚Äôs like the only book she has read more than once. It‚Äôs almost the only book she has read at all. So when fellow reviewers started reading and talking about Bridge of Clay, Markus‚Äôs long awaited new release, I started getting messages from them asking me what I thought, how was I going with it, did I agree about this or that. I had to admit, with a certain amount of bracing, that I, well, I just wasn‚Äôt going to read it because, you know, (at this point my voice would lower to a whisper as I uttered those last words) I don‚Äôt read Zusak. To their credit, they all still speak to me. Two friends, one of whom is also a reviewer, were not having a bar of this. You have to read Zusak, they said, but start with The Messenger. Now, I just want to clarify, that these two friends don‚Äôt know each other, but they both said pretty much the same thing to me. Eerily coincidental. I ordered a copy of The Messenger and here I am, no longer free of Zusak. My life will never be quite the same.

The Messenger is brilliant. There‚Äôs probably not a whole lot I could add to the existing commentary about The Messenger. It was published in 2002 and there are so many reviews out there written about it and so many online discussions about the ending. It‚Äôs got a feel to it that I really love. Through Ed, you slide into this existence of ordinariness that is so Australian and so very familiar. It‚Äôs funny, it‚Äôs tragic, it‚Äôs suspenseful, it‚Äôs romantic, it‚Äôs sometimes utterly ridiculous. I loved every single word of it. To me, The Messenger encompasses everything we need to know about being a decent human being. It may have been published 16 years ago, but its message is just as valid, if not more so, today. As we bump along in life, wrapped up in our dramas, increasingly isolating ourselves with our technology, we need to remember that there is validity in human connection. In taking notice, reaching out, and making a difference, even if it‚Äôs just in giving someone an ice-cream or really listening to what a person has to say. The small things can weigh in just as much as the big things. We need to avoid falling into the trap of never asking, never looking, and never listening. Ed put in me in mind of a guardian angel, but for Ed, being the messenger was not his only task, because as the novel progresses, it becomes apparent that there was a message hidden in there for Ed as well.

‚ÄòAlready, I know that all of this will stay with me forever. It‚Äôll haunt me, but I also fear it will make me feel grateful. I say fear because at times I really don‚Äôt want this to be a fond memory until it‚Äôs over. I also fear that nothing really ends at the end. Things just keep going, as long as memory can wield its axe, always finding a soft part in your mind to cut through and enter.‚Äô

The ending is rather powerful, but many don‚Äôt like it, and equally as many freely admit they don‚Äôt get it. I want to talk about the ending but without giving it away. Markus uses metafiction to pull off his ending, and for me, it really worked. But I had to think about it for a while, let it really sink in, because it re-orders everything about the novel and pushes the reader into a zone that they may not have inhabited before. In a nutshell, metafiction is fiction that is not only aware of its construction as a fiction, but also makes outright reference to that fact. The goal is to make the reader uncomfortable and question the line that exists between the fictional realm within the text and the world he or she inhabits. Supernatural, the TV show, does metafiction really well ‚Äì and once again I am able to demonstrate that all things can be clarified with an example from Supernatural, ha! They‚Äôve had several episodes across the seasons where Sam and Dean are parodied, even one that went so far as to have them pretending to be in a movie playing characters with their own real life names. And then there‚Äôs the well known storyline where they meet an author writing Supernatural fan fiction with events happening as the author writes them within the show. Confused? Sorry, it‚Äôs hard to explain but works well when you see it. In books, it‚Äôs obviously a bit more tricky. Nicholas Sparks used metafiction in the prologue and epilogue of his latest release, Every Breath. It didn‚Äôt work as well for me as what Markus Zusak has done here in The Messenger, but still, it‚Äôs a good example of the author placing themselves within their own text. Atonement is another example of metafiction in literature ‚Äì a very good example although it has its haters as well. Anyway, I‚Äôm going on a bit here so I‚Äôll get to the point. I like the ending of The Messenger. For me, it makes the whole point of the novel, the idea that we can all make a difference, no matter who we are, simply from observing and reaching out, all the more present. By suspending the fictional element through the use of metafiction, Markus is demonstrating that what Ed did, need not exist only in fiction. It can crossover into the real world. We too can be messengers. It doesn‚Äôt get more profound than that.

‚ÄòBut just remember that I was the one ‚Äì not him ‚Äì who gave life to these pages.‚Äô

To finish up, I just want to pay homage to The Doorman. Best stinky ice-cream eating coffee drinking loyal dog ever.

About the Author:

Markus Zusak was born in 1975 and is the author of five books, including I am the Messenger and the international bestseller, The Book Thief, which is translated into more than forty languages. He lives in Sydney with his wife and two children.
